October 27, 2013: Fiction
STORM FRONT, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) The Minnesota investigator Virgil
Flowers becomes involved in the hunt for an ancient inscribed stone smuggled out
of the Middle East.
DOCTOR SLEEP, by Stephen King. (Scribner.) Now grown up, Dan, the boy with
psycho-intuitive powers in “The Shining,” helps another threatened child with a
spectacular gift.
THE LONGEST RIDE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central.) The lives of two
couples converge unexpectedly.
GONE, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown.) Detective
Michael Bennett, living with his 10 adopted children on a California farm, is
pursued by the head of a Mexican drug cartel he once put in jail.
DOG SONGS, by Mary Oliver. (Penguin.) The dogs who have shared the life of
the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, in 35 poems and an essay.
STARRY NIGHT, by Debbie Macomber. (Ballantine.) At Christmastime, a big-city
columnist sets out to interview a reclusive author in Alaska.
THE CIRCLE, by Dave Eggers. (Knopf/McSweeney's.) A dystopian novel about
life on the campus of a powerful Internet company.
DOING HARD TIME, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam.) In the 27th Stone Barrington
novel, the New York lawyer teams up with a rogue former C.I.A. agent and heads
West to protect Barrington’s son and his friends from Russian assassins.
THE SIGNATURE OF ALL THINGS, by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking.) A 19th-century
botanist’s love of knowledge takes her to Tahiti; by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love.”
THE LOWLAND, by Jhumpa Lahiri. (Knopf.) After his radical brother is killed, an
Indian scientist brings his widow to join him in America.
DOOMED, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday.) In this sequel to “Damned,” Satan
has plans for a dead girl trapped in Purgatory (aka Earth).
THE QUEST, by Nelson DeMille. (Center Street.) Two journalists join an elderly
priest who has recently escaped from an Ethiopian jail in a search for a holy relic.
NEVER GO BACK, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) Jack Reacher is thrown into jail on
trumped-up charges.
W IS FOR WASTED, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) A homeless man
inexplicably leaves $600,000 to Kinsey Millhone.
THE FALL OF THE GOVERNOR, PART 1, by Robert Kirkman and Jay
October 27, 2013
Non-Fiction
KILLING JESUS, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) Jesus' life and times,
and the events leading up to his execution.
DAVID AND GOLIATH, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown.) How disadvantages
can work in our favor; from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.”
THE REASON I JUMP, by Naoki Higashida. (Random House.) A 13-year-old boy
with autism answers questions.
I AM MALALA, by Malala Yousafzai with Christina Lamb. (Little, Brown.) The
experience of the Pakistani girl who advocated for women’s education and was
shot by the Taliban.
MY STORY, by Elizabeth Smart with Chris Stewart. (St. Martin's.) A woman
kidnapped by religious fanatics from her Utah home in 2002 at age 14 describes
her captivity and rescue nine months later.
SI-COLOGY 1, by Si Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Tales
from Phil’s youngest brother, retired from the Army, who works in the Duck
Commander workshop.
ONE SUMMER, by Bill Bryson. (Doubleday.) The author of “A Short History of
Nearly Everything” describes the events of the summer of 1927: Charles
Lindbergh’s trans-Atlantic flight, Babe Ruth’s 60 homers, the great Mississippi
flood.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
TIP AND THE GIPPER, by Chris Matthews. (Simon & Schuster.) The host of
MSNBC’s “Hardball,” a former aide to Tip O’Neill, analyzes the former speaker’s
collegial relationship with President Reagan.
ZEALOT, by Reza Aslan. (Random House.) A biography of Jesus of Nazareth
presents him in the context of his times as the leader of a revolutionary movement.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
PRACTICE TO DECEIVE, by Ann Rule. (Gallery Books.) Sex, greed and scandal
motivate a murder on Washington State’s Whidbey Island.
FOCUS, by Daniel Goleman. (Harper.) The author of “Emotional Intelligence”
relies on research on attention to argue that high achievement requires three kinds
of focus.
